title-group.article-title: Association between the valine/leucine247 polymorphism of β2-glycoprotein I and susceptibility to anti-phospholipid syndrome: a meta-analysis

article-meta.aff: Division of Rheumatology, Department of Internal Medicine, Korea University College of Medicine, Seoul, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Young H Lee, Division of Rheumatology, Department of Internal Medicine, Korea University, Anam Hospital, Korea University College of Medicine, 126–1, Anam-dong 5-ga, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 136–705, Korea Email: lyhcgh@korea.ac.kr

abstract.p: Objective: The objective of this paper is to explore whether the valine/leucine247 (Val/Leu247) polymorphism of β2-glycoprotein I (β2GPI) confers susceptibility to anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS) and thrombosis and predicts positivity for anti-β2GPI antibodies. Methods: A meta-analysis was conducted on the associations between the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism and susceptibility to APS and thrombosis and positivity for anti-β2GPI. Results: A total of 1507 patients with APS and 1450 controls in 12 comparative studies were included in this meta-analysis. Meta-analysis of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism showed significant associations between the β2GPI Val allele and APS, thrombosis, and anti-β2GPI positivity (odds ratio (OR) 1.316, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.068–1.621, p = 0.010; OR 1.908, 95% CI 1.195–3.046, p = 0.007; OR 1.630, 95% CI 1.018–2.609, p = 0.042, respectively). A direct comparison between anti-β2GPI-positive and -negative patients revealed that the frequency of the Val allele was significantly higher in anti-β2GPI-positive patents (OR 1.514, 95% CI 1.017–1.253, p = 0.041). Furthermore, a direct comparison between thrombosis-positive and -negative patients also indicated that the Val/Val + Val/Leu and the Val/Val vs. Leu/Leu genotypes of the β2GPI polymorphism were significantly elevated in patients with thrombosis (OR 2.817, 95% CI 1.200–6.610, p = 0.017; OR 3.312, 95% CI 1.338–8.200, p = 0.010, respectively). Conclusion: This meta-analysis shows that the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism is associated with susceptibility to APS and thrombosis and with anti-β2GPI positivity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by arterial/venous thrombosis and recurrent fetal loss in the presence of anti-phospholipid (aPL) antibodies, such as lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin (aCL) antibodies and anti-β2glycoprotein-I (anti-β2GPI) antibodies.1,2 Although the etiology of APS is not fully understood, it has been suggested to occur when an individual with genetic susceptibility to the disease is exposed to certain environmental factors.3

aCL is directed against phospholipid-binding proteins, mainly β2GPI, which consists of a single polypeptide chain (326 amino acids) composed of five homologous domains of approximately 60 amino acids each (designated domains I to V) and domain V contains the major phospholipid bind site.4 The mechanism by which anti-β2GPI recognizes β2GPI remains unclear. However, several epitopes for anti-β2GPI antibodies have been known. Especially, the domain I of β2GPI is recognized as one of the major epitopes.4 The β2GPI gene, which maps to chromosome 17q23–24, has four major polymorphisms at positions 88, 247, 306 and 316.5 However, the effects of these polymorphisms on the properties of β2GPI have not been determined. The valine/leucine247 (Val/Leu247) polymorphism is located in domain V of β2GPI, which is a potential epitope site for anti-β2GPI antibodies.6 Furthermore, a polymorphism on or near the phospholipid-binding site of β2GPI could affect the binding or production of aCL.

The β2GPI Val247 allele has been reported to be associated with a higher frequency of anti-β2GPI and stronger reactivity with anti-β2GPI than the β2GPI Leu allele, which suggests that this allele may be a genetic susceptibility factor for the development of APS.7

The β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism has been studied in the context of susceptibility to APS, thrombosis and anti-β2GPI positivity.8–17 However, published genetic association results for the polymorphism are controversial, which could be due to small sample sizes, low statistical power and/or clinical heterogeneity. Therefore, in order to overcome the limitations of individual studies, resolve inconsistencies and reduce the likelihood that random errors are responsible for reported false positive or false negative associations,18–20 we turned to meta-analysis. In the present study, we sought to determine whether the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism contributes to susceptibility to APS, thrombosis and anti-β2GPI positivity using a meta-analysis approach.

sec.title: Identification of eligible studies and data extraction
sec.p: A literature search was conducted for studies that examined associations between the β2GPI polymorphism and APS. We utilized the MEDLINE citation index to identify articles (up to December 2011) that examined the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism in APS patients and controls. In addition, all references mentioned in identified articles were reviewed to identify studies not indexed by MEDLINE. The following key words and subject terms were searched, ‘antiphospholipid syndrome’, ‘APS’ and ‘polymorphism’ and the following information was extracted from each study identified: author; year of publication; ethnicity of the study population; demographics; numbers of cases and controls; the frequencies of genotypes and alleles of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism.

sec.title: Evaluation of publication bias and study quality
sec.p: Funnel plots are used to detect publication bias, but require a range of studies of varying sizes and subjective judgments and, thus, we evaluated publication bias using Egger’s linear regression test,21 which measures funnel plot asymmetry on a natural logarithm scale of odds ratios (ORs). The χ2 test was used to determine if observed genotype frequencies in controls conformed to Hardy–Weinberg (H-W) expectations.

sec.title: Evaluations of statistical associations
sec.p: We performed meta-analyses using: (1) the allelic contrast (Val vs. Leu); (2) the recessive (Val/Val vs. Val/Leu + Leu/Leu); (3) the dominant (Val/Val + Val/Leu vs. Leu/Leu); (4) the additive (Val/Val vs. Leu/Leu) models. Point estimates of risks, ORs and 95% confidence intervals (CI) were estimated for each study. In addition, within- and between-study variations and heterogeneities were assessed using Cochran’s Q-statistic. This heterogeneity test assesses the null hypothesis that all studies evaluated the same effect. The effect of heterogeneity was quantified using I2, which ranges between 0 and 100% and represents the proportion of between-study variability attributable to heterogeneity rather than chance.22 I2 values of 25%, 50% and 75% were nominally defined as low, moderate and high estimates. The fixed effects model assumes that a genetic factor has a similar effect on vasculitis susceptibility across all studies investigated and that observed variations among studies are caused by chance alone.23 The random effects model assumes that different studies show substantial diversity and assesses both within-study sampling error and between-study variance.24 When study groups are homogeneous, the two models are similar, but if this is not the case the random effects model usually provides wider CI than the fixed effects model. The random effects model is best used in the presence of significant between-study heterogeneity.24 Statistical manipulations were undertaken using a Comprehensive Meta-Analysis computer program (Biosta, Englewood, USA).

sec.title: Studies included in the meta-analysis
sec.p:
Altogether, 29 studies were identified by electronic and manual searches and 11 were selected for a full-text review based on title and abstract details.8–17,25 One of the 11 was excluded, because it did not include the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism.25 In addition, one of the eligible studies contained data on three different ethnic groups17 and these were treated independently.16,25 Thus, a total of 12 populations were considered in the meta-analysis and, in total, these contained 1507 patients and 1450 controls8–12,14–16 (Table 1). These 12 populations encompassed four European, three South American, two Asian, one African American, one mixed and one population of unknown ethnicity. In 10 of these 12 populations, the β2GPI polymorphism was examined in APS patients and controls, in eight the polymorphism was examined in anti-β2GPI (+) patients and controls, in nine the polymorphism was examined in anti-β2GPI (+) and anti-β2GPI (−) patients, in four the polymorphism was examined in thrombosis (+) patients and controls and in three the polymorphism was examined in thrombosis (+) and thrombosis (−) patients. Table 1 summarizes the details of the individual studies included in the meta-analysis. Table 1

sec.title: Meta-analysis of the associations between the t2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism and APS and anti-P2GPI positivity
sec.p:
Meta-analysis of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism showed significant associations between its V allele with APS and with anti-β2GPI positivity (OR 1.316, 95% CI 1.068–1.621, p = 0.010; OR 1.630, 95% CI 1.018–2.609, p = 0.042, respectively; Figures 1 and 2, Table 2). Analysis using the recessive or additive models also revealed a significant association between the polymorphism and APS (Table 2). Furthermore, a direct comparison between anti-β2GPI-positive and -negative patients revealed that the frequency of the V allele was significantly higher among anti-β2GPI-positive patents (OR 1.514, 95% CI 1.017–1.2.253, p = 0.041; Table 2). Two studies included aPL instead of anti-β2GPI, but we restricted the analysis to anti-β2GPI. However, when studies on aPL were excluded in the meta-analysis of the relationship between the polymorphism and anti-β2GPI status, the overall results were not substantially affected. Figure 1
Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals (CI) of individual studies and pooled data for the association between the valine (Val) allele of the β2glycoprotein-I Val/leucine247 polymorphism and anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS). Figure 2
Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals (CI) of individual studies and pooled data for the association between the valine (Val) allele of the β2glycoprotein-I (β2GPI) Val/leucine247 polymorphism and anti-β2GPI. Table 2

sec.title: Meta-analysis of the association between the e2GPI polymorphism and thrombosis
sec.p:
Meta-analysis showed a significant association between the presence of thrombosis and the β2GPI V allele (OR 1.908, 95% CI 1.195–3.046, p = 0.007) (Figure 3, Table 2). In particular, analysis using the recessive, dominant or additive models revealed significant associations between thrombosis and the β2GPI polymorphism (Table 2). A direct comparison between thrombosis-positive and -negative patients indicated that the frequencies of the Val/Val + Val/Leu genotype and the Val/Val vs. Leu/Leu genotype of the β2GPI polymorphism were significantly higher in patients with thrombosis (OR 2.817, 95% CI 1.200–6.610, p = 0.017; OR 3.312, 95% CI 1.338–8.200, p = 0.010, respectively; Table 2). Figure 3
Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals (CI) of individual studies and pooled data for the association between the valine (Val) allele of the β2glycoprotein-I Val/leucine247 polymorphism and thrombosis.

sec.title: Heterogeneity and publication bias
sec.p: The distributions of the genotypes of the β2GPI polymorphism in the control groups were consistent with the H-W equilibrium in populations studied, except for three populations.8,10,17 Deviation from the H-W equilibrium among controls implies the possibility of selection bias or genotyping errors. However, when these three populations were excluded, the overall results were not substantially affected. Some between-study heterogeneity was found by meta-analyses of APS vs. control, anti-β2GPI (+) vs. control and anti-β2GPI (+) vs. anti-β2GPI (−). However, no between-study heterogeneity was found by meta-analyses of the β2GPI polymorphism in thrombosis (+) vs. thrombosis (−), except for the V allele analysis (Table 2). Publication bias causes a disproportionate number of positive studies and poses a problem for meta-analyses, but Egger’s regression test showed no evidence of publication bias in any of the meta-analyses conducted during the present study (Egger’s regression test p-values >0.1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: APS is a complex autoimmune disease that demonstrates gene–gene and gene–environmental involvements. In particular, genetic variants may affect susceptibility to and the clinical manifestations of APS.Thus, interest in genetic susceptibility to APS and the clinical manifestations of genetic variants have encouraged studies on the effects of genetic polymorphisms on the pathogenesis of APS.3

However, results on the association between the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism and APS remain inconclusive.8–17 In this meta-analysis, we combined data from published studies on genetic associations between the most commonly studied polymorphism of the β2GPI gene, namely, the Val/Leu247 polymorphism and APS. Our meta-analysis showed a significant association between the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism and APS, thrombosis and anti-β2GPI positivity. In particular, a direct comparison between anti-β2GPI-positive and -negative patients revealed that the frequency of the Val allele was significantly higher in anti-β2GPI-positive patents (OR 1.514, 95% CI 1.017–1.253, p = 0.041). Furthermore, patients with anti-β2GPI antibody had a significantly higher V allele frequency than patients without anti-β2GPI. In addition, a direct comparison between thrombosis-positive and -negative patients also indicated a significant association between the β2GPI polymorphism and presence of thrombosis, suggesting that the β2GPI polymorphism is a risk factor of the development of thrombosis. Also, patients with thrombosis had a greater Val allele more frequently than did patients without thrombosis.

The strength of our results was based on large sample sizes included in this meta-analysis compared to subject numbers from individual studies. Meta-analysis of individual studies is a method to overcome the problem of small sample size and inadequate statistical power of genetic studies of complex traits and integrate previous research, providing increased statistical power and resolution by pooling the results of independent analyses. Results from the article with the biggest population studied were negative.10 However, 1507 APS patients were included and compared to 1450 healthy controls in this meta-analysis and we determined the contribution of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism to APS, thrombosis and anti-β2GPI using meta-analysis.

Then how could the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism affect susceptibility to APS and thrombosis and anti-β2GPI positivity? β2GPI is a major target antigen of aCL and the protein level of β2GPI is under genetic control. The β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism affects the electrostatic interaction between domains IV and V of β2GPI and, thus, causes structural changes at the autoantibody recognition site, which would affect affinity between anti-β2GPI and epitopes of β2GPI.12 Thus, the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism may affect the antigenicity of β2GPI for anti-β2GPI. In a previous study, anti-β2GPI was found to show more binding affinity for recombinant Val β2GPI than recombinant Leu β2GPI.12

A small alteration in the conformation of β2GPI arising from the Val/Leu substitution at position 247 could affect susceptibility to APS and thrombosis and anti-β2GPI positivity by increasing the propensity in patients with APS to generate autoreactive T cell clones. Ito et al.26 showed that CD4+ T cell clones react with peptide fragments, including amino acid positions 244–264 of β2GPI. Our meta-analysis findings are consistent with the notion that changes in β2GPI protein structure induce the generation of an antigenic β2GPI.

The present study has some limitations that should be considered. First, publication bias, heterogeneity and confounding factors may have distorted the meta-analysis. Data were not stratified by variables, such as primary or secondary APS, due to insufficient and limited information. Second, the frequencies of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism are quite different among races, which may affect the statistical significance in each small-size study. Limited data also prevented ethnic-specific meta-analysis. Thus, studies are required on different ethnic groups to clarify the role of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism more comprehensively in APS.

In conclusion, this meta-analysis of the association between the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism and APS shows that this polymorphism is weakly associated with susceptibility to APS and thrombosis and anti-β2GPI positivity. Furthermore, APS patients with anti-β2GPI positivity or thrombosis more frequently expressed the Val allele of the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism than APS patients without anti-β2GPI positivity or thrombosis. Accordingly, our findings support the notion that the β2GPI Val/Leu247 polymorphism plays a role, but is probably not crucial in the pathogenesis of APS by influencing development of anti-β2GPI and thrombosis.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by a grant from Korea University Medical Center.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
